newsitem.title: HONG KONG: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong Newspaper Headlines-Dec 20.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong Newspaper Headlines-Dec 20.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in Hong Kong's press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- WEN WEI PO -- With encouragement from China's central government in Beijing, Hong Kong leader-designate Tung Chee-hwa was more confident about Hong Kong's future. He would start to set up his government right away.
-- Tung called on civil servants to continue to work hard, and said he would try to arrange to meet Hong Kong Governor Chris Patten and Chief Secretary Anson Chan as soon as possible.

-- SING TAO -- Financial Secretary Donald Tsang acknowledged the property market was overheating but he was against using administrative measures to control it. He believed increasing land supply was the best way forward.

-- EXPRESS NEWS -- The last eunuch of China died on Dec 17 in Beijing aged 94. He became a eunuch at the age of eight, serving the last emperor Pu Yi and his family. His memories of life in the Forbidden City were recorded in his book "Secrets of the Last Eunuch".
-- MING PAO -- Shanghai's newly-developed Pudong area had attracted more than 300,000 labourers from all over the country, and 7,000 peasants had set up their own businesses there.

-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- Hong Kong gay rights groups were awarded grants for the first time yesterday, but those who missed out said the Government had missed the chance to set up Hong Kong's first gay and lesbian community centre.
-- China was attempting to create a major company in infrastructure development which might eventually be listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange.
-- According to a local estate agent, luxury residential prices were expected to surge a further 20 per cent in 1997.
-- HONGKONG STANDARD -- The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development believed Hong Kong's reversion to China could help spread the rule of law in business to China.
-- China's biggest securities company, Shenyin & Wanguo Securities, struck a joint venture deal with a U.S. mutual fund to set up a fund management operation in Hong Kong.
